text: you know I got to tell you all that I
like the president personally we get
along well but the president isn't
leading he didn't lead on last year's
budget and he clearly is not leading on
this year's budget in the private sector
back in Ohio Speaker John Boehner built
an entire career around being a great
salesman he made quite a bit of money
selling plastics and now that sort of
providing the framework for his greatest
sale here on Capitol Hill perhaps of his
legislative career so we're going to be
prepared to move forward with our troop
funding bill that would fund our troops
keep the government open for another
week and a cut 12 billion dollars in
spending mr. boehner has to sell a
spending package to members of his
caucus particularly freshman and the
more conservative members on a
compromise with Senate Democrats in the
White House that will probably be short
of the 60 1 billion dollar in cuts those
members were looking for mr. Boehner is
deeply aware of the pitfalls of a
government shutdown that be felled his
predecessors particularly Newt Gingrich
in 1995 while some of the freshmen are
far younger or have no government
experience whatsoever mr. Boehner is
completely aware how much that hurt the
Republican Party and how long that
damaged lasted mr. Boehner had a
conversation early Wednesday with
President Obama and said that he wanted
to avert a shutdown and then he would
continue to negotiate mr. Obama has made
it clear that the 40 billion dollars
which is reported to be the new bar that
mr. Boehner is looking to bring back to
his caucus in discretionary spending is
probably not going to happen now what he
has to do is go back to his members and
say look you may not get the number that
you want you may not get all the policy
writers such as defunding Planned
Parenthood or all abortion providers but
what you have is basically a
philosophical victory you've changed the
conversation from how to spend in
Washington to how to cut time when
you're struggling to pay your bills and
meet your responsibilities the least we
can do is meet our responsibilities to
produce a budget amid all the budget
fighting this week the president finds
himself in a sort of tricky position not
only is he trying to negotiate his way
out of a government shutdown with the
congressional Republicans he's also now
just having to react to the introduction
of the House Republicans budget for the
year beyond this one and it's a
long-range plan that is hugely ambitious
even radical in the way it would remake
the government but that's a fight for
another day now we're still trying to
get the spending for the last six months
of this year and avoid a government
shutdown this weekend White House
advisors for the most part see
opportunity ultimately for the president
but there are pitfalls as well the House
Republicans demands on the budget are so
far to the right that the White House
sees an opportunity for President Obama
to strike a middle ground ultimately
both in these current negotiations and
in the future budget that will be more
appealing to centrist voters
particularly independence but there's
also a pitfall in that does extent to
which the president stays on the
sidelines of these things above the fray
it feeds this narrative that Republicans
are trying to water that he's not really
leading and also the other pitfall is
that we see today with the president in
Pennsylvania talking about energy that
it sort of trods on his message talking
about clean energy and Hayek gas prices
he can't do that or where there's not so
